info.game_comments: Jason Zuffranieri game 6. Last game of Season 35.

(1, 1).clue: The name of this bridge is a contraction of rivo alto, "deep stream"

(2, 1).clue: To travel by taking rides from passing cars

(3, 1).clue: In 201 a U.K. game of this sport went 50 hours non-stop--"the only time we slept was when our team was batting"

(4, 1).clue: "The Heart Of Rock & Roll" lead singer who also wrote "Alice in Wonderland"

(5, 1).clue: This chess piece can only move in an L-shape

(6, 1).clue: It's your day off, go ahead & be one of these "spuds" & catch up on your favorite shows

(1, 2).clue: Now meaning a slum, this word may come from the name of a Venetian area to which Jews were once restricted

(2, 2).clue: Akin to saute, you do this to veggies in a wok

(3, 2).clue: Lee Corso once noted the Rainbow Warriors football team at this univ. "doesn't win many games in the United States"

(4, 2).clue: "Hit The Road Jack" with the singer & pianist who also came up with the theory of evolution by natural selection

(5, 2).clue: A traditional honeycomb is made of cells of this shape

(6, 2).clue: Chillax with your partner & enjoy a couple's one of these, maybe the Swedish type; it's just what you knead

(1, 3).clue: During one season, the winter o 1678, this Baroque music master was born in Venice

(2, 3).clue: To get behind the wheel of a Chrysler you're thinking of buying & take it for a spin

(3, 3).clue: Spin in an 8-foot, 2-inch throwing circle to throw a 4.4-pound circle in this sport

(4, 3).clue: Folk trio that was "Blowin' In The Wind" with the writer of "Frankenstein"

(5, 3).clue: Connect two semicircles with parallel lines & you have this shape, named for a type of arena

(6, 3).clue: Forget cooking--you can order food from this rhyming service that delivers from more than 105,000 takeout restaurants

(1, 4).clue: In 697 Paolo Lucio Anafesto became the first of these Venice bosses; in 1797 Ludovico Manin became the last

(2, 4).clue: To use a foot & a pedal to get a motorcycle going

(3, 4).clue: This "Brown Bomber" successfully defended his heavyweight crown 25 times, with 22 knockouts

(4, 4).clue: "Super Freak" singer who also told "Tales of the South Pacific"

(5, 4).clue: The shape created by two interlocking circles is called a vesica piscis, Latin for this bladder

(6, 4).clue: Enjoy a glass of the tawny type of this fortified wine

(1, 5).clue: St. Mark's is famous for this type of bell tower, from the Italian for "bell"

(2, 5).clue: To windmill, headspin or elbow hop like a b-boy

(3, 5).clue: Fox Sports:this Utah Jazz man, AKA the Mailman, "may be the first human to be even more chiseled than his own statue"

(4, 5).clue: "Raindrops Keep Fallin' On My Head" singer who takes up a pen & creates "The Mayor of Casterbridge"

(5, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew demonstrates the trammel of Archimedes.) Also known as a do-nothing machine, the trammel of Archimedes actually has a function--if you trace the path of the handle, you can draw one of these shapes

(6, 5).clue: Chillax to some classical music like this German composer's "Canon in D"; it's not just for weddings

(1, 1).clue: It was a bad day to be a robot sub as the one here felt the 2-ton bite of one of these apex predators, also known as the maneater

(2, 1).clue: Signing the Amer. w/ Disabilities Act on July 26, 1990, Pres. Bush said he was inspired by this GOP senator who lost the use of an arm

(3, 1).clue: Luckily for Starbucks, this server job is considered gender neutral in Italian

(4, 1).clue: In 1968 episode No. 1 of this news show that's still on had behind-the-scenes looks at Richard Nixon & Hubert Humphrey

(5, 1).clue: "Henry IV, Part 2": "He hath eaten me out of ____ and ____"

(6, 1).clue: As well as photosharing on this app, you can watch its Snap originals like "#vanlife"

(1, 2).clue: The subcutaneous lateral line on this tiger shark senses these quivering motions in the water, perhaps from a struggling fish

(2, 2).clue: On July 26, 1858 Baron Lionel de Rothschild took his seat as the first Jewish member of this government body

(3, 2).clue: In 1993 this term was used by writer Stephen Fried to describe members of a supermodel's entourage

(4, 2).clue: I'm so glad we had this woman's variety show that had Jim Nabors as its first guest & as the first guest each season

(6, 2).clue: Genus Antirrhinum, these flowers snap closed after they are pried open by bees

(1, 3).clue: Many sharks are solitary hunters, but reef sharks are known to hunt in this 11-letter way that also refers to a type of apartment

(2, 3).clue: The Continental Congress established this govt. entity July 26, 1775 with Ben Franklin as its first head

(4, 3).clue: In 1967 Harry Morgan joined "Dragnet" as Bill Gannon, the final partner of this police sergeant played by Jack Webb

(5, 3).clue: "Henry VI, Part 2":"The first thing we do, let's ____ all the ____"

(6, 3).clue: This singer decided to add the finger snaps to her hit song "Fever"

(1, 4).clue: Shark Week divers encounter a rare sight--a bigeye type of this shark, named for a motion its tail makes as it whips its prey

(2, 4).clue: Liberia dates its founding from the signing of its constitution in this city on July 26, 1847

(3, 4).clue: A native of Brazil's largest city

(4, 4).clue: One white guy, one black guy & one blonde gal fought crime as this cool undercover title trio

(5, 4).clue: "Romeo and Juliet": "It is the ____, and Juliet is the ____"
(5, 4).correct response: "It is the east, and Juliet is the sun"

(6, 4).clue: This hyphenated tool company owns brands like Car-O-Liner & Kansas Jack

(1, 5).clue: It was white-knuckle time on Shark Week as one of the crew got harassed by a huge one of these 4-letter sharks with a Maori name

(3, 5).clue: This type of soldier works out of Chiapas

(4, 5).clue: This animated cosmic superhero, voiced by Gary Owens, faced off against galactic villains

(5, 5).clue: A double double blank, from "Macbeth": "____ is ____, and ____ is ____"
(5, 5).correct response: "Fair is foul, and foul is fair"

(6, 5).clue: In 2019 meteorologist Daryl Ritchison at NDSU, this university, said the minus-33 temps were "a cold snap"

(0, 0).clue: 215 passengers were rescued when it sank in July 1918, about 500 fewer than it had rescued 6 years earlier
